Cicero ‘de Finibus,’ tv. xix. 35. states it thus: “Recte facta omnia aqualia, omnia peccataparia,” —a doctrine, as he says, very showy at first sight, but utterly unsound and contrary to common-sense. Horace, having dealt with one extrava- gance of this sect, proceeds to ridicule another, to wit. that a wize man was potentially master of all knowledge, all excellence, all power. In
